results.content:
David does slightly better at his delivery in this course. 

However, the curriculum is too short. Half of it is spent on basic Node/Express functions and not enough is spent on learning PSQL. 

This course would benefit more if there was an extra section on joining tables and deploying your database to a deployment server like heroku.
results.content_html:
David does slightly better at his delivery in this course.

However, the curriculum is too short. Half of it is spent on basic Node/Express functions and not enough is spent on learning PSQL.

This course would benefit more if there was an extra section on joining tables and deploying your database to a deployment server like heroku.

results.content: Overall, I liked the course - but it would be nice if there was a little more help with the windows part of it. Mainly, I was unable to get the database set up through the code and had to use pgAdmin to get it set up. After that, everything worked.
results.content_html: Overall, I liked the course - but it would be nice if there was a little more help with the windows part of it. Mainly, I was unable to get the database set up through the code and had to use pgAdmin to get it set up. After that, everything worked.

results.content: Misleading and badly taught.  This was NOT an "All Levels" course - you must have lots of experience with Javascript, JSON, Postman, Visual Studio, etc.  This is a "type this type this type this okay moving on type this type this..." course at breakneck speed - NO explanation of what's going on, what the code is doing.  In nearly every lecture, the code does not work and I had to ask questions to get it to run.  I had to stop and rewind each lecture a dozen times because the instructor speaks so very fast with poor annunciation.  And then I had to pause each lecture a dozen times just to look up concepts that he doesn't explain.  And, in the end, he never actually tell you how to connect a website to a PostgreSQL database.  Don't waste your money.
results.content_html: Misleading and badly taught. This was NOT an "All Levels" course - you must have lots of experience with Javascript, JSON, Postman, Visual Studio, etc. This is a "type this type this type this okay moving on type this type this..." course at breakneck speed - NO explanation of what's going on, what the code is doing. In nearly every lecture, the code does not work and I had to ask questions to get it to run. I had to stop and rewind each lecture a dozen times because the instructor speaks so very fast with poor annunciation. And then I had to pause each lecture a dozen times just to look up concepts that he doesn't explain. And, in the end, he never actually tell you how to connect a website to a PostgreSQL database. Don't waste your money.

results.content: This course is a good introduction to NodeJS and ExpressJS, but you should take a different course for learning about the best practices of SQL/PostgreSQL. Databases created in this course are simple, not normalized, and sometimes redundant. However, if you want to learn how to use node and connect to your databases, this course does a good job of walking through how to do that.
results.content_html: This course is a good introduction to NodeJS and ExpressJS, but you should take a different course for learning about the best practices of SQL/PostgreSQL. Databases created in this course are simple, not normalized, and sometimes redundant. However, if you want to learn how to use node and connect to your databases, this course does a good job of walking through how to do that.

results.content:
The material in the program is actually very good. However it is outdated and I did not realize that when I purchased the course.

Additionally there is no support from the author. He does not respond to questions on the lessons or direct messages. I don't know if he is more engaged in newer courses or if he is even still making courses. 

It's a shame because the material is enjoyable to go through but I imagine it's difficult to balance responding to so many students, while maintaining a full time job.

results.content: No explanation on object destructuring. Would be good to see what is inside the express.router() to understand why the express object has a router function in it and what's actually inside to understand the mechanics of why it works. Right now, a lot of the concepts are still quite 'magical', don't know how it actually works at the base level. Also, should try and incorporate code breaking a lot more to understand why some syntaxes are so important.
results.content_html: No explanation on object destructuring. Would be good to see what is inside the express.router() to understand why the express object has a router function in it and what's actually inside to understand the mechanics of why it works. Right now, a lot of the concepts are still quite 'magical', don't know how it actually works at the base level. Also, should try and incorporate code breaking a lot more to understand why some syntaxes are so important.

results.content:
This was my first intro to PostgreSQL. I studied a bit of Node.js and decided for my back end development I wanted to use the two together. I come from a strong SQL Server background and didn't see courses that coupled SQL Server with Node.js. This is a good course for a beginner of Node.js and PostgreSQL. However, many of the concepts seemed advanced to me and I really struggled with following along on a Windows environment. I've used a Mac but don't own one. It would have been helpful to have asides for Window's users. For instance, using GitBash and adding sh in front of the path for the configure script in the package.json file was key in allowing me to continue past that point. I found these suggestions after a few hours searching through the Q/A and on the web. I was so discouraged but persisted. 
I think David did a great job in the course layout and content. He obviously knows the subject matter VERY well and introduces concepts that I know I will use going forward. For me, his delivery could be a bit slower along with pausing a bit more before jumping to a new screen. I had to pause and "rewind" constantly to make sure I got it. 
Also, I wonder if anyone uses the pgAdmin 4 interface to manipulate the databases. It would have been nice to work with that. I'd also like to see a front end wired up that pulled everything together. 
And lastly, for the websites I host that will need a back end, it would be great to see how to deploy to Heroku. I saw another request for that. That is my end goal for sure as a freelance, full stack developer. 
Thank you David, for your time and dedication to the field. I'm very grateful and wish you the best always!
results.content_html:
This was my first intro to PostgreSQL. I studied a bit of Node.js and decided for my back end development I wanted to use the two together. I come from a strong SQL Server background and didn't see courses that coupled SQL Server with Node.js. This is a good course for a beginner of Node.js and PostgreSQL. However, many of the concepts seemed advanced to me and I really struggled with following along on a Windows environment. I've used a Mac but don't own one. It would have been helpful to have asides for Window's users. For instance, using GitBash and adding sh in front of the path for the configure script in the package.json file was key in allowing me to continue past that point. I found these suggestions after a few hours searching through the Q/A and on the web. I was so discouraged but persisted.
I think David did a great job in the course layout and content. He obviously knows the subject matter VERY well and introduces concepts that I know I will use going forward. For me, his delivery could be a bit slower along with pausing a bit more before jumping to a new screen. I had to pause and "rewind" constantly to make sure I got it.
Also, I wonder if anyone uses the pgAdmin 4 interface to manipulate the databases. It would have been nice to work with that. I'd also like to see a front end wired up that pulled everything together.
And lastly, for the websites I host that will need a back end, it would be great to see how to deploy to Heroku. I saw another request for that. That is my end goal for sure as a freelance, full stack developer.
Thank you David, for your time and dedication to the field. I'm very grateful and wish you the best always!

results.content:
The course covers all the necessary topics, but there are some coding standards that I do not agree with, like declaring imports as constants.

Please provide explanation for why things are done in a specific way.

response.content: Named imports in Node.js aren't available for a good reason that's explained here: https://medium.com/the-node-js-collection/an-update-on-es6-modules-in-node-js-42c958b890c
response.content_html: Named imports in Node.js aren't available for a good reason that's explained here: https://medium.com/the-node-js-collection/an-update-on-es6-modules-in-node-js-42c958b890c

results.content: Nice! This course will get you up and running with Node, Express, and Postgres. I took a more detailed Postgres course and found this to be a breeze. The course shows you how to work with express to handle http requests, connect to your database and read/insert/update/delete data, and send and receive that data to/from a client. Follow closely with the monsters project and build, tear apart and rebuild your code to see how everything works.
results.content_html: Nice! This course will get you up and running with Node, Express, and Postgres. I took a more detailed Postgres course and found this to be a breeze. The course shows you how to work with express to handle http requests, connect to your database and read/insert/update/delete data, and send and receive that data to/from a client. Follow closely with the monsters project and build, tear apart and rebuild your code to see how everything works.

results.content:
This course is pretty good. I was a bit surprised it ended where it did, given that the only real output we got was the query results in json. It would have been nice to make a basic app to interpret the json data into a frontend interface like "show me a monster" and then it tells you about the monster along with data from the other tables (like habitat info, etc.) as this (in my opinion) would be the most practical for folks like myself who are trying to make frontend apps using node/postgres as the backend. David's pacing is pretty quick so I ended up rewinding many times per lecture just to catch certain syntax edits he did on the fly. While he punctuates his speech with the appropriate amount of pauses, it kind feels like a robot sometimes and there really isn't much variability of tone or emphasis (auditory cues to help absorb context).

All in all, definitely worth the $12 I paid for it. It will be a challenge for sure to adapt the code I've written to my own project (that I wanted to build this kind of backend for) but I'm sure I'll go back into some of these lectures to understand what's doing what. One highlight here is that I ended up writing the same code for things like the callback functions so many times that I really did understand their role better, so props for including sufficient repetitive practice in that regard, David. 

I would give this a 3.5 / 5, but given the choice between 3 and 4, I'm inclined to round up due to the effort and comprehensiveness of this course.

results.content: This is a decent course but it is slightly DATED especially for Linux users but I've gone slightly grey trying to simply set up PostgreSQL 11 on my system I bought this item in Nov 28 2018. Please update this baby your style of teaching is not bad but please help later users.
results.content_html: This is a decent course but it is slightly DATED especially for Linux users but I've gone slightly grey trying to simply set up PostgreSQL 11 on my system I bought this item in Nov 28 2018. Please update this baby your style of teaching is not bad but please help later users.

results.content:
This course was a mixed experience for me.  In the early sections, I was extremely impressed with the way that the instructor unpacked some names and terminology that often go overlooked, even in much longer and more comprehensive courses on the same topics.

This was also the first course I've taken where some more operational and practical things were explained such as creating executables, configurations, and environment variables.  Unfortunately, this was directed only at people using Macs.  Using Windows, many of the instructions did not work for me and I had to troubleshoot them on my own.

Finally, the instructor raced through the building of the final application, which is where there was real opportunity to provide the same kind of clear insights that I so appreciated in the early part of the course.

In summary, on the one hand, I appreciated the focus on setting up a SQL database, creating a basic API, the terminology unpacking, and some practical operational exposure.  On the other hand, the building of the final API was raced through without the same attention to detail offered in the earlier sections.  I think a beginner would be quickly lost in this course, but it's worth the short amount of time if you want to learn the basics of connecting a Node API with a PostgreSQL database.
results.content_html:

This was also the first course I've taken where some more operational and practical things were explained such as creating executables, configurations, and environment variables. Unfortunately, this was directed only at people using Macs. Using Windows, many of the instructions did not work for me and I had to troubleshoot them on my own.

Finally, the instructor raced through the building of the final application, which is where there was real opportunity to provide the same kind of clear insights that I so appreciated in the early part of the course.

In summary, on the one hand, I appreciated the focus on setting up a SQL database, creating a basic API, the terminology unpacking, and some practical operational exposure. On the other hand, the building of the final API was raced through without the same attention to detail offered in the earlier sections. I think a beginner would be quickly lost in this course, but it's worth the short amount of time if you want to learn the basics of connecting a Node API with a PostgreSQL database.

results.content:
I was rather scared to take a course of this length, as I expected not so much content. Luckily, I was wrong and I learnt some new stuff especially later in the course. 
This course is nice when you have some time to spent, since the content is not too difficult. However, if you are woring on Windows you have to do a lot of own research. The command are most often not suitable for Windows. Maybe installing Git Bash Terminal would have changed that. I also got problems in the last 2 sections - redirecting after a post and deleting something in general. If I get a proper answer on the Q-A section, I would give this course 4 out of 5 stars.

results.content: This was a great introduction to Node, Express and Postgres. Aside from using the frameworks and learning to create and interact with Postgres databases, David also throws in lots of tips and tricks for streamlining your startup and development Node scripts with executable files and bash scripts.
results.content_html: This was a great introduction to Node, Express and Postgres. Aside from using the frameworks and learning to create and interact with Postgres databases, David also throws in lots of tips and tricks for streamlining your startup and development Node scripts with executable files and bash scripts.

results.content: I love the thorough definitions! As a full front-ender (with basic BE knowledge), this course really helped me with understanding the magicks that's happening in the backend, the databases and API's. Im also happy that it's using expressJS, since it is a popular framework with a large community. Thanks for making it as understandable as you could. I also wish you covered more advanced sql queries, I felt that part was a bit lacking. But thank you! The course was overall great.
results.content_html: I love the thorough definitions! As a full front-ender (with basic BE knowledge), this course really helped me with understanding the magicks that's happening in the backend, the databases and API's. Im also happy that it's using expressJS, since it is a popular framework with a large community. Thanks for making it as understandable as you could. I also wish you covered more advanced sql queries, I felt that part was a bit lacking. But thank you! The course was overall great.

results.content: Really nice course, but I would've loved that he teached us more about security on our web api's since that's essential. So if you're only looking on how to use postgres with Node JS this is just fine, but if you're looking for a detailed explanation about Node Web Api's and Sql databases, this is not for you!

results.content: Amazing course for anyone who knows nothing about Nodejs, SQL or PostgreSQL. Very good explanations & create lecturer! The only reason I don't give it 5 starts is because I feel like the PostgreSQL side was very fast and could be explored more. Especially around using something like pgAdmin. There were also a few big bumps as a Windows user. Other than that the course was really good! :)

results.content:
What I liked the most:
- quickly up and running with Express and Postgres
- scripting for the development environment setup automation

What should be improved:
- does not demonstrate, how to handle missing data on requests
- error handling should be improved to give relevant information to the API user (what's wrong with the request)
- does not demostrate the proper use of HTTP status codes
- thus, the API design itself should be improved.
results.content_html:

results.content:
A useful but rather expensive course of node.js API + PostgreSQL. Valuable only if you leverage on better courses about RESTful APIs with node.js.

Some nice takeaways:
--- A very nice section about PosgreSQL.
--- Simple and short (a bit too much, really...), making it a handy reference.
--- Some nowadays forgotten but useful basics, like revisiting the use of `curl` for  Acceptance Testing before turning back to Postman, or how to create an executable file for the server.
--- Reminds the effects of relying on json files as data source.

This course is either an introduction or a complement for other courses.
results.content_html:
